MARYLAND TWELVE TOMORROW
AFTERNOON AT HOMEWOOD

Championship. Coach Schmeisser Now Settled on
Permanent Team

game last Saturday the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team is all afire to

which they plan to dispose of Maryland as they did Navy. Maryland too is on edge for the battle, smarting from two defeats.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

A RUSHING AGREEMENT
Although next year, with its problems, appears to be a very minute spot on the horizon of the future, it is by no means too early to
advocate certain steps which seem to be necessary. One of these
steps is the adoption of a fraternity rushing agreement for the coming year.
Much deliberation and discussion obviously are necessary before
an agreement can be reached. It can not be expected that any season will be ideal to each crowd. The only thing we hope for is that
each chapter will be broad-minded enough to see that some season
is agreed upon which will be for the interests of the fraternities as a
whole and, therefore, make some sacrifice. Incidentally, such an
agreement would be most beneficial to the University. Advocates
of the long rushing period claim that such a season would benefit the
University since it would not interfere with the training of football
men. They point out also that the long period would provide time in
which the fraternity and the new man could look each other over and
thus prevent many regrets on both sides. On the other hand, upperclassmen occupy a great amount of their time in rushing new members, and, as a consequence, the studies and activities of both the
Freshmen and upperclassmen suffer. Naturally, the longer the period of rushing, the greater the amount of neglect of the studies. It
is believed that a rushing season at least a month shorter would eliminate these faults, and at the same time, allow sufficient time for new
men and fraternities to make up their minds concerning bids.
Certainly the present situation of deadlock can be improved upon
by compromise, and the proper time to reach an agreement is NOW.
How about it, fraternity men?

"FIDELIA" A NOVEL OF COLLEGE
LIFE, APPEALS TO COLLEGIANS
THE NEWS-LETTER, believing that a college student should be able
to judge of the truth contained in a novel purporting to be about American college life, has asked a prominent Senior to review "Fidelia," by
E. Balnier.
"What did Professor Smith mean
this morning when he told you
that no man could ever make a
silk purse out of a sow's ear?"

THE MAIL BAG
An intercepted letter, doubtless
intended for the Mailbag, bewails
the degeneracy of Hopkins into the
high school stratum. Apparently
the descent has been a gradual process, the last step being taken by
the "administration" when it shortened the Easter holidays by a day.
The author gives none of the
other steps, so we can't dispute the
hypothesis that Johns Hopkins was
a single step from the odious high
school stage until the recent ruling.
The plan for ascent which our
writer advocates seems to us an
excellent one. If a day off the holiday period is a step down, then a
day added on is most certainly a
niche gained in the upward movement—the more days we have free
from study, the higher we will climb
toWard the pinnacle of American
universities. Zito!

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

A RUSHING AGREEMENT
Although next year, with its problems, appears to be a very minute spot on the horizon of the future, it is by no means too early to
advocate certain steps which seem to be necessary. One of these
steps is the adoption of a fraternity rushing agreement for the coming year.
Much deliberation and discussion obviously are necessary before
an agreement can be reached. It can not be expected that any season will be ideal to each crowd. The only thing we hope for is that
each chapter will be broad-minded enough to see that some season
is agreed upon which will be for the interests of the fraternities as a
whole and, therefore, make some sacrifice. Incidentally, such an
agreement would be most beneficial to the University. Advocates
of the long rushing period claim that such a season would benefit the
University since it would not interfere with the training of football
men. They point out also that the long period would provide time in
which the fraternity and the new man could look each other over and
thus prevent many regrets on both sides. On the other hand, upperclassmen occupy a great amount of their time in rushing new members, and, as a consequence, the studies and activities of both the
Freshmen and upperclassmen suffer. Naturally, the longer the period of rushing, the greater the amount of neglect of the studies. It
is believed that a rushing season at least a month shorter would eliminate these faults, and at the same time, allow sufficient time for new
men and fraternities to make up their minds concerning bids.
Certainly the present situation of deadlock can be improved upon
by compromise, and the proper time to reach an agreement is NOW.
How about it, fraternity men?

An intercepted letter, doubtless
intended for the Mailbag, bewails
the degeneracy of Hopkins into the
high school stratum. Apparently
the descent has been a gradual process, the last step being taken by
the "administration" when it shortened the Easter holidays by a day.
The author gives none of the
other steps, so we can't dispute the
hypothesis that Johns Hopkins was
a single step from the odious high
school stage until the recent ruling.
The plan for ascent which our
writer advocates seems to us an
excellent one. If a day off the holiday period is a step down, then a
day added on is most certainly a
niche gained in the upward movement—the more days we have free
from study, the higher we will climb
